issues.description: The problem statement instructs students to call a save method that accepts a boolean 'force' flag (e.g., save(..., true)), but the provided template and the solution both use the standard Spring Data JPA save(Person) method without any boolean parameter. This mismatch will confuse students who try to follow the instructions (they may attempt to call a nonexistent save(person, true) method) and prevents implementing the described call as-is.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the problem statement with the actual repository API. Remove the instruction that the save method accepts a boolean 'force' flag and instead tell students to call the standard personRepository.save(person) and return its result. Alternatively (less preferred), add and document an overloaded save(Person, boolean) in the repository implementation in the template and solution—but updating the problem statement to match the standard JPA save signature is the simpler, clearer fix.

issues.description: The problem statement requires calling a save(...) method with a boolean flag 'force' set to true when persisting a modified Person (e.g., in addParent). However, both the template and the solution repositories expose PersonService.save(Person) and the underlying repository uses the standard JpaRepository save(Person) signature — there is no save(Person, boolean) overload or 'force' parameter in the code. This mismatch between the documented API (a save method that accepts a 'force' boolean) and the actual code will confuse students implementing addParent/addChild/removeParent/removeChild because they are instructed to call a method signature that does not exist in the starter code.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the problem statement and the code. Either (A) update the problem statement to remove the instruction about a 'force' boolean parameter and instruct students to call the existing save(Person) method (this matches the template and solution), or (B) add a matching overloaded save(Person, boolean force) to the service/repository (and implement its behavior) so the documented API exists in code. Preferred minimal fix: update the problem statement text to require calling personRepository.save(person) (no 'force' parameter) so instructions match the provided starter code.
